01-01.title: Mary Mother of God
01-01.description: Mary is the Mother of Jesus Christ, who is true God and true man. Being the Mother of God, Mary is endowed by God with special privilege. The Redemption began with Mary's 'yes' to the word of God. This feast was celebrated in the East before it was in the West, but by the 5th century it was celebrated in France and Spain on the Sunday before Christmas. In Rome, even before the 7th century, 1 January was used as a celebration of the Maternity of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

01-03.title: Holy Name of Jesus
01-03.description: The feast has been celebrated in the Roman Catholic calendar of saints, at least at local levels, since the end of the fifteenth century. The veneration of the Holy Name was extended to the entire Roman Catholic Church on 20 December 1721, during the pontificate of Pope Innocent XIII. The celebration has been held on different dates, usually in January, because 1 January, eight days after Christmas, commemorates the circumcision of the child Jesus; as recounted in the Gospel read on that day.

01-06.title: Epiphany
01-06.description: Epiphany, meaning 'manifestation', celebrates Jesus being revealed to the whole world. Represented by the Magi, all nations are called to adore Him. The feast dates back to the 3rd century in the East, where it originally took precedence over Christmas. In Jerusalem, Christ's birth was celebrated on January 6 until 549 AD, before being fixed on December 25 in the West around 380 AD, with Epiphany on January 6. The Eastern Churches continue to emphasize Christ's baptism as the central theme. Historically, Epiphany also commemorated other manifestations of Christ, including the wedding at Cana and the visit of the Magi, all of which were believed by some to have occurred on January 6.

01-09.title: Birthday of St. Josemaría (1902)
01-09.description: St. Josemaría Escrivá was born on January 9, 1902, in Barbastro, Spain. He would go on to found Opus Dei, a movement within the Church dedicated to helping people seek holiness in their everyday work and life. His birth marks the beginning of a life deeply committed to prayer, sacrifice, and the spreading of the universal call to holiness. From a young age, Josemaría demonstrated great spiritual sensitivity and would later respond to God's call with heroic generosity, influencing countless souls through his writings and example.

01-23.title: The Father's Election and Appointment
01-23.description: This date commemorates the appointment and canonical election of the current Prelate of Opus Dei. The feast marks the moment the Church confirms the new successor of St. Josemaría to lead the Prelature, following the procedures outlined in its statutes. Affectionately referred to as 'the Father', he is tasked with preserving its charism, guiding its members, and promoting holiness in ordinary life. The celebration reflects both gratitude and renewed commitment to the mission of Opus Dei under the leadership of its current Father.

01-24.title: Our Lady of Peace
01-24.description: Our Lady of Peace, Mother of Peace, Queen of Peace or Our Lady Queen of Peace is a title of the Blessed Virgin Mary. Crowned on July 9, 1906, she is represented holding a dove and an olive branch. Her memorial is celebrated on January 24 in Hawaii and some churches in the United States. Elsewhere, it is celebrated on July 9. Our Lady of Peace is the patroness of the Congregation of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, founded by Peter Coudrin in Paris during the French Revolution. In the Philippines, Our Lady of Peace interceded for the quiet protesters in 1986.

01-24.title: St. Francis de Sales
01-24.description: Born in Thorens, Savoy (France), St. Francis de Sales (1567-1622) fought Calvinism. He was Bishop of Geneva. With St. Francis Fremyot de Chantal, he founded the Order of the Visitation. He wrote Introduction to the Devout Life, a classic of spiritual direction. He died in Lyons and was canonized in 1655. In 1877, Pius IX proclaimed him Doctor of the Church. Pius XI declared him as Patron Saint of Journalists and Other Writers.

01-25.title: Conversion of St. Paul
01-25.description: The conversion of Saul of Tarsus, while he was on his way to Damascus to arrest more Christians (c. 33 to 36), is one of the most touching miracles of the history of the early Church: Paul ceased persecuting the Church and became a follower of Christ. Today, the Church prays for the unity of all Christians.

01-28.title: St. Thomas Aquinas
01-28.description: St. Thomas (1224-1274) received his education at the Abbey of Monte Cassino and at the University of Naples. In 1244 he joined the Dominican Order. Considered one of the greatest philosophers and theologians of all times, St. Thomas gained the title of "Angelic Doctor". He had an undisputed mastery of scholastic theology and a profound holiness of life. Pope Leo XIII declared him Patron of Catholic Schools. His monumental work, the Summa Theologica, was still unfinished when he died.

02-02.title: Presentation of the Lord
02-02.description: The feast was first observed in the Eastern Church as 'The Encounter.' In the sixth century, it began to be observed in the West, in Rome, with a more penitential character, and in Gaul (France) with solemn blessings and processions of candles, popularly known as 'Candlemas.' The presentation of the Lord concludes the celebration of the Nativity and, with the offerings of the Virgin Mother and the prophecy of Simeon, the events now point towards Easter.

02-11.title: Our Lady of Lourdes
02-11.description: This day marks the first apparition of the Blessed Virgin Mary in 1858 to fourteen-year old Marie Bernade (St. Bernadette) Soubirous. There were eighteen apparitions in all, the last of which was on 16 July 1858. The message of Lourdes is a call to personal conversion, prayer, and charity.

02-14.title: Women in Opus Dei (1930)
02-14.description: On February 14, 1930, St. Josemaría Escrivá received a divine light to begin admitting women into Opus Dei. This moment signified that the universal call to holiness applied equally to men and women, and that both could fully live the spirituality of Opus Dei in their ordinary life and work. The foundational inspiration on this day opened the path for countless women to find God through professional work, family life, and social engagement, while fostering a vibrant apostolic presence in the world.

02-14.title: Priestly Society of the Holy Cross (1943)
02-14.description: The Priestly Society of the Holy Cross, intrinsically united to Opus Dei, was founded on February 14, 1943, by St. Josemaría Escrivá. It offers spiritual support and formation to diocesan priests who seek holiness in the exercise of their ministry. Through the Society, these priests are helped to deepen their unity with the diocesan bishop while living the spirit of Opus Dei. The date marks a decisive step in the expansion of the Work's apostolic outreach to include clergy, as part of its mission to sanctify the world from within.

02-14.title: Mary Mother of Fairest Love
02-14.description: Mary, Mother of Fairest Love, is a title that expresses the deep Marian devotion of St. Josemaría and Opus Dei. Under this title, the Virgin Mary is honored as the perfect example of pure and self-giving love. The feast is observed on February 14 in Opus Dei, tying together the foundational inspirations of that day with Marian tenderness and guidance. Devotion to Mary under this name encourages the faithful to grow in affection for her, and to imitate her loving, silent presence in the midst of daily life

02-22.title: Chair of St. Peter
02-22.description: From the earliest times the Church at Rome celebrated on 18 January the memory of the day when the Apostle held his first service with the faithful of the Eternal City. According to Duchesne and de Rossi, the "Martyrologium Hieronymianum" (Weissenburg manuscript) reads as follows: "fifteenth day before the calends of February, the dedication of the Chair of St. Peter the Apostle in which Peter the Apostle first sat at Rome". The Epternach manuscript (Codex Epternacensis) of the same work, says briefly: "cath. petri in roma" (the Chair of Peter in Rome). In its present (ninth-century) form the "Martyrologium Hieronymianum" gives a second feast of the Chair of St. Peter for 22 February.

02-24.title: Decretum Laudis (1947)
02-24.description: On February 24, 1947, the Holy See granted Opus Dei the Decretum Laudis (“Decree of Praise”), officially recognizing it as a universal institution within the Church. This marked a decisive moment in the development of the Work, affirming the supernatural origin of its spirit and mission. The Decretum Laudis acknowledged Opus Dei's role in promoting holiness in ordinary life and opened the door to its expansion worldwide. The date is celebrated with thanksgiving, recalling the Church's confirmation of the Work's charism and apostolic fruitfulness.

03-19.title: St. Joseph
03-19.description: St. Joseph, the foster father of our Lord, is considered the second greatest saint, next to the Blessed Virgin Mary. He lived a holy and silent life beside Jesus and Mary, giving us example of an ordinary life lived to the full. March 19 is the principal feast day of St. Joseph and was dedicated to him in several Western calendars by the tenth century; this custom was also established in Rome by 1479. Pope St. Pius V extended its use to the entire Roman Rite. Pope Pius IX named him Patron of the Universal Church and Pope John XXIII included his name in the Roman Canon.

03-24.title: St. Gabriel the Archangel
03-24.description: St. Gabriel the Archangel is known as the heavenly messenger who announced the Incarnation to the Blessed Virgin Mary. His name means “God is my strength,” and he appears in Scripture bringing messages of profound significance—to Daniel, to Zechariah about John the Baptist, and to Mary at the Annunciation. March 24 was traditionally observed as his feast day, particularly in connection with the Annunciation on March 25. Although now celebrated jointly with the other archangels on September 29, this date remains a moment to reflect on Gabriel's role in salvation history and the mystery of divine communication.

03-25.title: Annunciation
03-25.description: The Feast of the Annunciation of the Blessed Virgin Mary was probably originated shortly before or after the council of Ephesus (c. 431). All Christian antiquity (against all astronomical possibility) recognized the 25th of March as the actual day of Our Lord's death. The opinion that the Incarnation also took place on that date is found in the pseudo-Cyprianic work "De Pascha Computus", c. 240. The Annunciation was the moment when St. Gabriel the Archangel communicated to Mary that she was to be the Mother of the Son of God. Through her consent to God's plans, she took part in the whole redemptive work of her Son, Jesus. We venerate her as the Mother of Christ and our Mother.

03-28.title: Priestly Ordination of St. Josemaría (1925)
03-28.description: On March 28, 1925, St. Josemaría Escrivá was ordained a priest in Zaragoza, Spain. His ordination was a pivotal step in God's plan for his life and the future founding of Opus Dei. As a young priest, he dedicated himself wholeheartedly to prayer, sacramental ministry, and seeking God's will. This date is remembered with gratitude, marking the beginning of a priestly life that would inspire thousands to pursue holiness through ordinary work and daily responsibilities, guided by the spirit of Opus Dei.

04-23.title: First Communion of St. Josemaría (1912)
04-23.description: On April 23, 1912, at the age of ten, St. Josemaría Escrivá received his First Holy Communion. This intimate encounter with Christ in the Eucharist would leave a deep and lasting impression on his soul. From that day onward, he nurtured a strong love for the Blessed Sacrament, which became a central pillar of his spiritual life and priestly mission. The date is remembered with special affection in Opus Dei, encouraging the faithful to renew their devotion to the Eucharist and to approach it with the same reverence and joy that marked the saint's first encounter.

04-25.title: St. Mark
04-25.description: He was the son of Mary in whose house Peter sought refuge after being freed from jail. He aided St. Paul and St. Barnabas in the evangelization of Cyprus. Later, Mark became the companion and secretary of St. Peter in Rome. He wrote the second Gospel which emphasizes the miraculous powers of the Savior. According to tradition, in AD 49, about 19 years after the Ascension of Jesus, Mark founded the Church of Alexandria. He became the first bishop of Alexandria and he is honored as the founder of Christianity in Africa. He was martyred in AD 68 at Alexandria by pagans who placed a rope around his neck and dragged him through the streets.

04-27.title: Miraculous Healing of St. Josemaría
04-27.description: On April 27, 1931, St. Josemaría Escrivá experienced a sudden and complete healing from a serious and prolonged illness that had left him extremely weak. The healing, which occurred after he entrusted himself with deep faith to God through the intercession of Our Lady, was understood by him as a sign to continue the mission God had entrusted to him: the founding and development of Opus Dei. This day is celebrated with gratitude for God's providence and serves as a reminder of the power of trust, perseverance, and prayer in moments of trial.

04-29.title: St. Catherine of Siena
04-29.description: St. Catherine (1347-1380) was a responsible instrument for the return of Pope Gregory XI from Avignon to Rome. In deed and in truth, she showed her love for God's Church and the Roman Pontiff. With her short life she gave us a lesson of courage: the courage of telling the truth for love of the Church and of souls. Imprinted with the sacred stigmata, she died in Rome at thirty-three years of age. She was proclaimed patroness of Italy on 18 June 1939. In 1970 Pope Paul VI proclaimed her Doctor of the Church.

05-01.title: St. Joseph the Worker
05-01.description: This feast was instituted in 1955 by Pope Pius XII and is celebrated on May 1, which is the day when labor is honored in many countries. In the Gospel Jesus was called "the son of the carpenter". This feast reminds us that honest work, no matter how seemingly menial, can be sanctified. Through work, we can sanctify ourselves and others, making each of us participants in the work of redemption.

05-02.title: Prelatic Church Anniversary
05-02.description: On May 2, 1986, the Church of Our Lady of Peace in Rome was dedicated as the Prelatic Church of Opus Dei. Located near the central offices of the Prelature, it serves as the spiritual heart of Opus Dei and the location of St. Josemaría's tomb. This anniversary is an occasion to give thanks for the physical and spiritual center from which the Work continues to radiate its mission: to sanctify ordinary life and work.

05-03.title: Ss. Philip and James
05-03.description:
Like Peter and Andrew, St. Philip was from Bethsaida. He was crucified at Hierapolis in Phrygia where he had preached the Gospel. He introduced St. Bartholomew to Christ. Christ declared to Philip, "He that hath seen me, hath seen the Father... I am in the Father and the Father in me." (John 14:8-9).
St. James was a cousin of our Lord. He was called James the Less, to distinguish him from the other James. As Bishop of Jerusalem, he wrote one of the epistles of the New Testament. St. James was thrown down from the terrace of the Temple and then stoned to death. The names of Philip and James are mentioned in the Roman Canon.

05-12.title: Blessed Álvaro del Portillo
05-12.description: Álvaro del Portillo (1914-1994) was the successor of St. Josemaría and the first Prelate of Opus Dei. A civil engineer by profession, he was known for his humility, fidelity, and deep love for the Church. He worked closely with St. Josemaría for decades and guided Opus Dei through its establishment as a Personal Prelature. Pope Francis beatified him in 2014. His feast day on May 12 commemorates his quiet strength, joyful service, and example of being a faithful shepherd to those entrusted to him.

05-13.title: Our Lady of Fátima
05-13.description: Our Lady of Fátima - at times Our Lady of the Rosary, by the name the three children called her - is a title given to the Blessed Virgin Mary as she appeared in apparitions reported by three shepherd children at Fátima in Portugal. These occurred on the 13th day of six consecutive months in 1917, starting on May 13. The three children were Lúcia Santos and her cousins Jacinta and Francisco Marto. Her message was one of hope, repentance, and conversion for the whole world.

05-14.title: St. Matthias
05-14.description: After the ascension of our Lord, St. Peter proposed that the disciples select an apostle in the place of Judas. The choice was Matthias, who joined the eleven apostles. According to Nicephorus, St. Matthias first preached the Gospel in Judaea, then in Aethiopia (in modern-day Georgia) and was crucified in Colchis. Another tradition says that he worked for the Faith in Palestine, and later was stoned at Jerusalem by the Jews, and then beheaded (d.64).

05-17.title: Beatification of St. Josemaría (1992)
05-17.description: On May 17, 1992, Pope St. John Paul II beatified Josemaría Escrivá in a solemn ceremony in St. Peter's Square. The event drew pilgrims from all over the world and confirmed the Church's recognition of the holiness of his life and the fruitfulness of his message. In his homily, the Pope praised St. Josemaría's tireless promotion of the universal call to holiness. This day is remembered with joy and gratitude, as it marks the Church's formal affirmation of the sanctity of a priest who taught that every path on earth can be a path to God.

05-18.title: Blessed Guadalupe Ortiz de Landázuri
05-18.description: Guadalupe Ortiz de Landázuri (1916-1975) was a laywoman and one of the first women to join Opus Dei. A chemist by training, she combined deep faith with professional excellence, bringing the spirit of Opus Dei to Mexico and later moving to Rome. She offered her work, friendships, and ordinary life to God with joy and simplicity. Pope Francis beatified her in 2019, recognizing her heroic virtue and intercessory power. Her life is a radiant example of holiness in daily life, especially for women in science and education.

05-30.title: Saint's Day of the Father
05-30.description: This date marks the liturgical feast of the saint whose name the current Prelate of Opus Dei bears. As the Prelate's personal patron, this celebration varies depending on who holds the office. It is a moment for members of Opus Dei and those close to the Work to express affection, gratitude, and prayerful support for their spiritual Father. The day highlights the paternal role of the Prelate as a successor of St. Josemaría, guiding the Prelature with fidelity, charity, and a spirit of service.

05-31.title: Visitation
05-31.description: The Visitation commemorates the visit of the Blessed Virgin Mary to her cousin Elizabeth, as recorded in the Gospel of Luke. Upon greeting Mary, Elizabeth, filled with the Holy Spirit, recognized the Mother of the Lord, and the unborn John the Baptist leapt in her womb. Mary responded with the Magnificat, a hymn of praise to God. This feast highlights Mary's charity, humility, and joy in serving others. It also celebrates the recognition of Christ's presence even in the hiddenness of the womb, and the powerful witness of maternal faith.

06-11.title: St. Barnabas
06-11.description: He was a Cypriot Jew. The Holy Spirit destined him to a universal mission. It was Barnabas who introduced St. Paul to the other apostles. He was with Paul in the first missionary journey and in the first Council of Jerusalem. Although the date, place, and circumstances of his death are, as yet, historically unverifiable, Christian tradition holds that Barnabas was martyred at Salamis, Cyprus, in 61 AD. He is traditionally identified as the founder of the Cypriot Church.

06-16.title: Definitive Approval of Opus Dei (1950)
06-16.description: On June 16, 1950, the Holy See granted definitive approval to Opus Dei as a secular institute, formally recognizing its mission and spirituality within the life of the Church. This milestone confirmed the universal vocation to holiness in ordinary life, which St. Josemaría had preached since 1928. The definitive approval was a profound moment of joy and gratitude for the Work, affirming its fidelity to the Church and opening the way for its continued growth.

06-22.title: St. Thomas More
06-22.description: John Fisher (1469-1535) studied Theology in Cambridge (England) and became Bishop of Rochester. St. Thomas More (1477-1535) was born in London, England and was Chancellor of King Henry VIII. St. John Fisher and his friend St. Thomas More gave up their lives in testimony to the unity of the Church and to the indissolubility of Marriage. They suffered martyrdom under King Henry VIII.

06-24.title: St. John the Baptist
06-24.description: Born six months before our Lord, St. John the Baptist was the son of Zachary and Elizabeth, cousin of our Lady. He was the last and greatest of the prophets. As the forerunner of the Savior, his mission was to prepare the Jews for the coming of Christ. When Jesus had come, St. John bore witness to Him before his own followers and encouraged them to follow Him.

06-25.title: Priestly Ordination of the First Priests of Opus Dei (1944)
06-25.description: On June 25, 1944, the first three members of Opus Dei were ordained to the priesthood: Álvaro del Portillo, José María Hernández de Garnica, and José Luis Múzquiz. This marked a historic moment in the life of the Work, as the priestly dimension of its mission became visibly rooted in sacramental ministry. These men were chosen from among lay members, showing that Opus Dei's priesthood arises from the same spirit of sanctifying ordinary life. Their ordination embodied the unity of lay and priestly vocations in the service of the Church.

06-26.title: St. Josemaría
06-26.description: St. Josemaría (1902-1975) founded Opus Dei on October 2, 1928, which opened a new path within the Church which enabled men and women of all conditions to live the fullness of their Christian vocation. He taught people in all walks of life how to become holy by living a Christian life and performing their ordinary work and daily duties well. In 1982 Opus Dei was established as a Personal Prelature.

06-29.title: Ss. Peter and Paul
06-29.description: The Church founded by Christ has Sts. Peter and Paul as its principal pillars. Peter was chosen by Christ to be His first Vicar on earth, endowed with powers of the keys of the Kingdom of Heaven (Mt 16:13-19) and charged with the role of Shepherd of Christ's flock (Jn 21:15-17). In Peter and his successors, the visible sign of unity and communion in faith and charity has been given. St. Peter suffered martyrdom under Nero, in A.D. 66 or 67. He was buried at the hill of the Vatican, today the site of St. Peter's Basilica. Paul was chosen an instrument to bring Christ's name to all peoples (Acts 9:15), he is the greatest missionary of all times. St. Paul was beheaded in the Tre Fontane along the Via Ostiense and buried nearby, on the spot where the basilica bearing his name now stands.

07-03.title: St. Thomas
07-03.description: Among the apostles, Thomas is remembered mainly because of his doubts about the resurrection of Christ. He did not want to admit anything that went beyond the bounds of his experience and reason. Eight days later he made up for that unbelief with a profession of faith, "My Lord and my God" (Jn 14:5-6). Thomas preached in Southeast Arabia, the Malabar Coast, and India. According to tradition, St. Thomas attained martyrdom at St. Thomas Mount in Chennai. In 232 most of the relics of the Apostle Thomas are said to have been brought by an Indian king to the city of Edessa, Mesopotamia.

07-16.title: Our Lady of Mount Carmel
07-16.description: This feast was established in 1726 to commemorate the apparition of the Blessed Virgin to St. Simon Stock, the Superior General of the Carmelite Order, on July 16, 1251. To him she promised a special blessing for everyone who wears her scapular. Since then, the Church has solemnly and repeatedly approved this devotion which began in England. For centuries, Christians have taken advantage of the protection promised by the Blessed Virgin. The devout use of the scapular shows our trust in the Blessed Virgin's motherly aid to help us at the hour of our death.

07-22.title: St. Mary Magdalene
07-22.description: St. Mary Magdalene was one of the few who remained with Christ during His agony on the cross. With two other women, she went to His tomb and found it empty. It was to her that our Lord first appeared after His resurrection. He asked her to announce His resurrection to the apostles. The Eastern Orthodox Church maintains that Mary Magdalene, distinguished from Mary of Bethany and the "sinful woman", had been a virtuous woman all her life. According to Eastern traditions, she retired to Ephesus with the Theotokos (Mary, the Mother of God) and there she died. Her relics were transferred to Constantinople in 886 and are preserved there.

07-25.title: St. James the Greater
07-25.description: He is called "the Greater" because his vocation to serve Christ preceded that of the other apostle of the same name. He was the son of Zebedee, and was called by Jesus together with his brother John. James was one of the three apostles, along with Peter and John, who witnessed the Transfiguration (Mathew 17:1) and the agony in the Garden of Gethsemane (Mathew 26:37). He was condemned to death by Herod Agrippa and beheaded in the year 44, the first martyr among the apostles.

07-26.title: Ss. Joachim and Anne
07-26.description: It was in the home of Joachim and Anne where the Virgin Mary received her training to be the Mother of God. This devotion to Ann and Joachim is an extension of the affection Christians have always professed toward our Blessed Mother. Tradition has it that the parents of the Blessed Virgin, who, apparently, first lived in Galilee, came later on to settle in Jerusalem; there the Blessed Virgin was born and reared; there also they died and were buried. A church was built during the fourth century, possibly by St. Helena, on the site of the house of St. Joachim and St. Anne. In the ninth century, the church was converted into a Moslem school. The crypt which formerly contained the holy tombs was rediscovered on 18 March, 1889.

08-02.title: Our Lady of the Angels
08-02.description: This feast commemorates the finding of the image of Our Lady of the Angels or Queen of Angels at Cartago, Costa Rica, in 1636, which became the foundation of her Basilica. The devotion to Our Lady of the Angels has spread widely throughout the Catholic world.

08-04.title: St. John Mary Vianney
08-04.description: Born near Lyons, France, St. John (1786-1859) was ordained priest in Grenoble and assigned to the parish of Ars where he spent most of his life. He was outstanding for his steadfast care of souls, for his spirit of prayer and mortification, but above all, for his tireless dedication to the Sacrament of Penance. He spent close to 42 years in the confessional, drawing energy from his intimate and constant friendship with our Lord in the Eucharist. Pius XI declared him Patron of the Universal Clergy.

08-05.title: Dedication of St. Mary Major Basilica
08-05.description: After the declaration of the dogma of the divine Maternity of the Blessed Virgin in the Council of Ephesus (year 431), Pope Sixtus III dedicated this Basilica in Rome in honor of the Mother of God. It was called "St Mary Major" later on. It is considered the oldest church in the West dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary.

08-06.title: Transfiguration
08-06.description: This feast became widespread in the West in the 11th century and was introduced into the Roman calendar in 1457 to commemorate the victory over Islam in Belgrade. Before that, the Transfiguration of the Lord was celebrated in the Syrian, Byzantine, and Coptic rites. The Transfiguration foretells the glory of the Lord as God, and His ascension into heaven. It is an anticipation of the glory in heaven, where we shall see God face to face. We already share in this life, through grace, in the divine promise of eternal life.

08-15.title: Assumption
08-15.description: This feast was celebrated in the liturgy of the Eastern World from the sixth century and, in Rome, from the seventh century. On November 1, 1950 Pope Pius XII defined the dogma of the Assumption. He solemnly proclaimed that the belief whereby the Blessed Virgin Mary, at the close of her earthly career, was taken up body and soul, into the glory of heaven, really forms part of the deposit of faith, received from the apostles.

08-21.title: St. Pius X
08-21.description: Born near Venice to a very humble family, St. Pius X (1835-1914) distinguished himself for his continuous service to the Church and to all souls - first as priest, later as bishop and Patriarch Archbishop of Venice, and finally as the Roman Pontiff. He strongly defended the purity of Catholic doctrine against modern heresies. He instilled dignity to sacred liturgy and extended the practice of frequent communion.

08-22.title: Queenship of Mary
08-22.description: This celebration was instituted by Pope Pius XII in 1954. Mary participates in the glorious and universal kingdom of Christ. The foundation of this privilege of Mary is her intimate association with the Redemption performed by her Son. She is also the mediatrix of grace. Though not the source of grace, she is the channel through which grace is distributed to everyone. Let us have recourse to Mary in all our needs.

08-23.title: Ut Sit (1982)
08-23.description: On August 23, 1982, Pope John Paul II established Opus Dei as the first personal prelature of the Catholic Church through the apostolic constitution "Ut Sit". This canonical form recognized the unique character of Opus Dei's mission: to spread the call to holiness in ordinary life through professional work and daily duties. The establishment as a personal prelature ensured unity of spirit and governance under a Prelate, while allowing faithful from all walks of life to participate. This anniversary is celebrated with gratitude for the Church's trust and confirmation of the Work's path.

08-24.title: St. Bartholomew
08-24.description: St. Bartholomew was from Cana in Galilee. Mentioned in the Gospel as one of the twelve apostles, he is identified as "Nathanael" who was brought to Jesus by his friend, the apostle Philip. Along with his fellow apostle Jude, St. Bartholomew is reputed to have brought Christianity to Armenia. Thus both saints are considered the patron saints. He is said to have been martyred in Albanopolis by the brother of king Polymius for converting him.

09-08.title: Nativity of Our Lady
09-08.description: The Church, in keeping a solemn feast for the birthday of the Blessed Virgin Mary, celebrates the dawning of the Redemption over the world when, after a long period of waiting, she who was to be the Mother of our Savior was born. The Blessed Virgin occupies a unique place in the history of salvation. Heaven rejoices at her birth. The Lord reserves for her the highest mission ever commended to any creature. The feast may have originated somewhere in Syria or Palestine in the beginning of the sixth century, when after the Council of Ephesus, the devotion to the Mother of God was greatly intensified, especially in Syria.

09-12.title: Holy Name of Mary
09-12.description: The Feast of the Most Holy Name of Mary, or simply the Holy Name of Mary, is a feast day to honor the name of Mary the mother of Jesus. It has been a universal Roman Rite feast since 1684, when Pope Innocent XI included it in the General Roman Calendar to commemorate the victory at the Battle of Vienna in 1683. The feast day began in 1513 as a local celebration in Cuenca, Spain.

09-14.title: Exaltation of the Holy Cross
09-14.description:
Our Mother the Church sings of the triumph of the Holy Cross, the instrument of our salvation. In order to follow Christ, the Christian must take up his cross and become obedient with Christ, who was obedient until death, even death on the Cross.
The feast of the Exaltation of the Cross sprang at Rome at the end of the seventh century. The 3rd of May was called the feast of the Invention of the Cross, and it commemorated in a special manner Saint Helena's discovery of the sacred wood of the Cross; the 14th of September, the feast of the Exaltation of the Cross, commemorated above all the circumstances in which Heraclius recovered from the Persians the True Cross, which they had carried off.

09-15.title: Our Lady of Sorrows
09-15.description: This feast has its origin in that Christian devotion which associates her with the Passion of her Son. Pope Pius VII extended this devotion to the whole Church and, in 1912, St. Pius X fixed the feast on this day, within the octave of the Nativity of our Mother the Virgin. Our Mother the Virgin teaches us to live, together with her, beside the Cross of her Son. In her suffering as co-redeemer, she reminds us of the tremendous malice of sin and shows us the way of true repentance.

09-21.title: St. Matthew
09-21.description:
Also called Levi, St. Matthew was the son of Alphaeus. He was a publican, that is, a tax collector for the Romans. His profession was hateful to the Jews. Nevertheless, our Lord called him. Matthew's vocation reminds us that sanctity is not reserved for privileged persons. Tradition unanimously acknowledges him as the author of the first Gospel, written in Aramaic, the language that our Lord himself spoke, and translated into Greek afterwards.
For 15 years, St. Matthew preached the Gospel in Hebrew to the Jewish community in Judea, before going to other countries and dying a martyr. Ancient writers do not agree as to what these countries are, but others say that he went to Persia.

09-24.title: Our Lady of Ransom
09-24.description: Our Lady of Ransom is the principal patron of Barcelona. The Blessed Virgin appeared to St. Peter Nolasco (1189-1256) in the city of Barcelona - at that time of the Kingdom of Aragon, and showed him the white habit of the order of The Royal, Celestial and Military Order of Our Lady of Mercy and the Redemption of the Captives, founded for the redemption of Christian captives. One of the distinguishing marks of the Order of the Blessed Virgin Mary of Mercy is that, since its foundation, its members are required to take a Fourth Vow to die for another who is in danger of losing their Faith.

09-29.title: Archangels
09-29.description: The liturgy celebrates the feast of these three archangels who are venerated in the tradition of the Church. Michael ('Who is like God?') was the archangel who fought against Satan and all his evil angels. He is our protector against the devil. Gabriel ('Strength of God') announced to Zachariah the coming birth of John the Baptist, and to Mary, the birth of Jesus. Raphael ('Medicine of God') is the archangel who took care of Tobias on his journey. Every person on his pilgrimage through this life also has a guardian angel with a mission similar to that of Raphael.

10-02.title: Founding of Opus Dei (1928)
10-02.description: On October 2, 1928, during a retreat in Madrid, St. Josemaría Escrivá received the foundational light to begin Opus Dei. He saw clearly that God was calling him to spread a message: that all people are called to holiness in their ordinary lives—through work, family, and daily responsibilities. This moment marked the birth of the Work, which would grow to become a worldwide reality within the Church. The date is celebrated as a moment of thanksgiving for God's grace and the beginning of a path that continues to transform countless lives.

10-02.title: Guardian Angels
10-02.description: This celebration was placed in the Roman calendar in 1615. Scripture is full of narrations involving the special intervention of angels. The Church believes that each person has his own Guardian Angel. Angels are God's messengers whose mission is to take care of our material and spiritual needs, to protect us, to show us God's will, and to guide us to heaven. The New Testament encourages us to imitate the naturalness with which the first Christians dealt with the angels.

10-06.title: Canonization of St. Josemaría
10-06.description: On October 6, 2002, Pope John Paul II canonized Josemaría Escrivá in St. Peter's Square before a vast gathering of faithful from around the world. Declaring him a saint, the Pope affirmed the universal relevance of his message: that ordinary life is a path to holiness when lived with love for God and others. In his homily, the Pope called him "the saint of ordinary life." The canonization is celebrated with joy and renewed commitment to spreading the Gospel through the sanctification of work, family, and daily duties.

10-07.title: Our Lady of the Rosary
10-07.description: This Marian celebration originated from the victory of Lepanto (1571). The combined Christian fleet defeated the forces of the Turks, thus arresting their occupation of Europe. This favor was attributed by Pope St. Pius V to the recitation of the Holy Rosary. The Blessed Virgin Mary has revealed in numerous apparitions that the Rosary is her favorite prayer. The Popes and many saints have recommended the recital of the Rosary as well. The elements of the Holy Rosary are two: the meditation of the mysteries and the vocal prayer.

10-11.title: Anniversary of the Nihil Obstat (1943)
10-11.description: On October 11, 1943 — then the feast of the Divine Maternity of Mary — the Holy See granted the "nihil obstat" for the canonical erection of the Priestly Society of the Holy Cross, intrinsically united to Opus Dei. This marked a significant milestone in the juridical development of the Work, affirming that nothing stood in the way of its formal establishment in the Church. From the earliest days, St. Josemaría had prayed earnestly for a juridical path that would preserve the foundational charism he had received. The "nihil obstat" was a quiet but decisive answer to those prayers.

10-12.title: Our Lady of the Pillar
10-12.description: This is a very special feast day as it is Our Lady's first known apparition. What makes this apparition so special is that Our Lady was still living on earth when it took place. According to an ancient tradition, the Apostle James the Greater was instructed by Mary to build a chapel where he was praying by the banks of the Ebro at Saragossa.

10-18.title: St. Luke
10-18.description: A physician from Antioch, he was converted to the Christian faith. He was a disciple of St. Paul and a faithful companion in all his journeys. He was the author of the third Gospel and of the Acts of the Apostles. He was the evangelist who wrote about the childhood of Jesus and who has told us some of the most moving parables of the Lord, such as that of the lost sheep and the prodigal son. Luke died at age 84 in Boeotia. Luke's Tomb was located in Thebes (Greece), from whence his relics were transferred to Constantinople in the year 357.

10-22.title: St. John Paul II
10-22.description: Karol Józef Wojtyła was born in 1920 in Wadowice, Poland. After years of hardships during and after World War II, his ordination and intensive work, he became first auxiliary bishop and, in 1964, Archbishop of Krakow and took part in the Second Vatican Council. On 16 October 1978 he was elected pope and took the name John Paul II. His exceptional apostolic zeal, particularly for families, young people and the sick, led him to numerous pastoral visits throughout the world. He died on 2 April 2005 in Rome, and was canonized by Pope Francis on 27 April 2014.

10-28.title: Ss. Simon and Jude
10-28.description: St. Simon is usually called the "Cananean" and also "the Zealot", probably because he belonged to the Jewish party of "the Zealots of the Law". St. Jude, also called Thaddeus or "Courageous", is the author of a short epistle in the New Testament. St. Simon is often associated with St. Jude as an evangelizing team. The most widespread tradition is that after evangelizing in Egypt, Simon joined Jude in Persia and Armenia or Beirut, Lebanon, where both were martyred in 65 AD.

11-01.title: All Saints
11-01.description: Today we celebrate the feast of all the unknown saints who are now in heaven. The Church reminds us that sanctity is within everyone's reach. Through the communion of saints we help one another achieve sanctity. In the early days the Christians were accustomed to solemnize the anniversary of a martyr's death for Christ at the place of martyrdom. In the fourth century, neighboring dioceses began to interchange feasts, to transfer relics, to divide them, and to join in a common feast. Gregory III (731-741) consecrated a chapel in the Basilica of St. Peter to all the saints and fixed the anniversary on 1 November.

11-08.title: St. Severinus
11-08.description: Details about the life and death of St Severinus are not known. He was a Roman Soldier who suffered martyrdom under Emperor Marcus Aurelius at Vienne, Gaul (d.170) together with Exuperius, and Felician.

11-21.title: Presentation of Mary
11-21.description: According to Exodus 13:2 and 12, all the Hebrew first-born male children had to be presented in the Temple. Such a law would lead pious Jewish parents to observe the same religious rite with regard to other favorite children. Apocryphal writings and tradition state that Joachim and Anna presented the child Mary in the Temple when she was three years old and that she made her vow of virginity on this occasion. This feast is mentioned for the first time in a document in 1166 and in 1585 Pope Sixtus V extended the Feast of the Presentation to the whole Church.

11-27.title: Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal
11-27.description: In 1830 in France, St. Catherine Laboure was visited by the Blessed Virgin Mary three times.  During the second apparition, St. Catherine saw our Lady standing on a globe with rays of light streaming from her hands and the words, "O Mary conceived without sin, pray for us who have recourse to Thee." Our Lady told St. Catherine to have a medal made. The medals were called the Medal of the Immaculate Conception and, because many favors were given to the people wearing the medal, it became the Miraculous Medal.

11-27.title: Death of the Grandfather (1924)
11-27.description: This day commemorates the death of St. Josemaría's maternal grandfather, Don José. Though a personal and family remembrance rather than a liturgical feast, it holds meaning within Opus Dei as a moment to reflect on the value of family heritage, memory, and intercession. St. Josemaría often drew strength from the love and example of his relatives, including his grandfather. The day invites the faithful to pray for the souls of their own deceased loved ones and to deepen their sense of spiritual continuity across generations.

11-28.title: Erection of Opus Dei as a Personal Prelature (1982)
11-28.description: On November 28, 1982, Pope St. John Paul II erected Opus Dei as a personal prelature through the apostolic constitution Ut Sit, bringing to completion the long-sought juridical path envisioned and prayed for by St. Josemaría Escrivá. This milestone was the fruit of years of prayer, sacrifice, and tireless fidelity to the mission God entrusted to him on October 2, 1928. St. Josemaría once wrote that the Work advanced "on the basis of prayer: of my prayer, and my wretchedness… and of the prayer of so many souls." This anniversary is a day of profound gratitude to God for His providence and the Church's loving confirmation of the Work's vocation.

11-30.title: St. Andrew
11-30.description: Born at Bethsaida, he was a disciple of John the Baptist before he became a follower of Christ, to whom he also brought his brother, Peter. With Philip he presented the Gentiles to Christ. Before the miracle in the desert, he pointed out to Christ the boy carrying the loaves and fishes. It is said that St. Andrew preached along the Black Sea and the Dnieper and Volga rivers as far as Kiev and Novgorod. Hence he became a patron saint of Ukraine, Romania and Russia. According to tradition, he founded the See of Byzantium, Constantinople, in AD 38. He was put to death by crucifixion at Achaia.

12-06.title: St. Nicholas of Bari
12-06.description: St. Nicholas (270-343), also called Nikolaos of Myra, was a Greek Bishop of Myra (Demre, part of modern-day Turkey) in Lycia. Because of the many miracles attributed to his intercession, he is also known as Nikolaos the Wonderworker. He had a reputation for secret gift-giving, such as putting coins in the shoes of those who left them out for him, and thus became the model for Santa Claus, whose modern name comes from the Dutch Sinterklaas, itself from a series of elisions and corruptions of the transliteration of "Saint Nikolaos." In 1087, some of his relics were brought to Bari, in southeastern Italy, and for this reason, he is also known as Nikolaos of Bari. The remaining bones were taken to Venice in 1100.

12-08.title: Immaculate Conception
12-08.description: Pope Pius IX instituted this celebration when he proclaimed the dogma on December 8, 1854. In that definition, he expressed the exact meaning of the truth of Mary's Immaculate Conception and affirmed the constant faith of the Church, that she was conceived free from stain of original sin. This feast has been celebrated in the East since the eighth century and later, in many places in the West. This privilege of Mary is the most beautiful fruit of her Son's Redemption. Christ came to take away the sin of mankind; he did not allow sin to contaminate his Mother.

12-10.title: Our Lady of Loreto
12-10.description: Since the fifteenth century, and possibly even earlier, the Holy House of Loreto, a town south of Ancona, has been numbered among the most famous shrines of Italy. The basilica preserves the veritable cottage of Nazareth where our Lady received the message from the Angel Gabriel and the Word of God became incarnate. The believe in the miraculous transfer of the house of Nazareth to Loreto has been approved by Popes and acknowledge by saints. Loreto has been for centuries the scene of numerous miraculous cures and studies on the mortar and stone show that they came from Nazareth. The Santa Casa does not rest and has never rested upon foundations sunk into the earth where it now stands.

12-12.title: Our Lady of Guadalupe
12-12.description: In 1531 a "Lady from Heaven" appeared to a humble Native American at Tepeyac, a hill northwest of what is now Mexico City. She identified herself as the ever virgin Holy Mary, Mother of the True God. She made a request for a church to be built on the site. When the Bishop hesitated, and requested her for a sign, the Mother of God sent Juan Diego to him with roses in his tilma, which became the imprinted miraculously image of herself. Juan Diego's tilma, a poor quality cactus-cloth, has shown no sign of decay for close to 500 years, defying all scientific explanations.

12-25.title: Christmas
12-25.description: Christmas or Christmas Day (Old English: Cristesmaesse, literally "Christ's mass") commemorates the birth of Jesus Christ. It closes the Advent season and initiates the twelve days of Christmastide. The precise year of Jesus' birth, which some historians place between 7 and 2 BC, is unknown. By the early-to-mid 4th century, Western Christianity had placed Christmas on December 25, a date later adopted in the East. The date of Christmas may have initially been chosen to correspond exactly with the day of the Annunciation, nine month earlier, and the fact that Rome celebrated the feast of the sun on that day - Christ being the "Sun of righteousness." The original date of the celebration in Eastern Christianity was January 6, in connection with Epiphany, and that is still the date of the celebration for the Armenian Apostolic Church.

12-26.title: St. Stephen
12-26.description: He was the first Christian martyr. Stones outside Jerusalem, he died praying for his executioners. He was one of the seven deacons who helped the apostles. History approximates Stephen's death around A.D. 34-35, shortly after Jesus' crucifixion. God worked many miracles through St. Stephen and he spoke with such wisdom and grace that many of his hearers became followers of Jesus. The Church draws a comparison between the disciple and the Master, emphasizing the imitation of Christ up to the complete gift of self. His name is in the Roman Canon.

12-27.title: St. John
12-27.description: Born in Bethsaida, St. John together with James, his brother, and Simon Peter, was one of the witnesses of the Transfiguration. He wrote the fourth Gospel, three Epistles and the Apocalypse. He is the evangelist of the divinity of Christ and of fraternal love. At the Last Supper, he leans on the Master's breast. At the foot of the cross, Jesus entrusts his Mother to his care. John's pure life kept him very close to Jesus and Mary. St. John was exiled to Patmos in the reign of the Emperor Domitian (81-96). Previous to this, according to Tertullian's testimony, John had been thrown into a cauldron of boiling oil before the Porta Latina at Rome without suffering injury. After Domitian's death the Apostle returned to Ephesus during the reign of Trajan, and at Ephesus he died about A.D. 100 at a great age.

12-28.title: Holy Innocents
12-28.description: The Church celebrates the memory of the small children of the neighborhood of Bethlehem. They were put to death by Herod, who was seeking to kill Jesus. These innocent victims bear witness to Christ to a world which would not receive Him. The Latin Church instituted the feast of the Holy Innocents at a date now unknown, not before the end of the fourth and not later than the end of the fifth century. The feast is kept within the octave of Christmas because the Holy Innocents gave their life for the newborn Savior.

12-30.title: Holy Family
12-30.description: Devotion to the Holy Family is a recent development, but one that naturally grows out of a love for Jesus and his family.
